briefdescription.para: typedef to Traits::Point_d.

detaileddescription.para: Point type used to represent the input points.

briefdescription.para: typedef to Traits::FT.

detaileddescription.para: Number type used to return the squared distance between the two polytopes.

briefdescription.para: typedef to Traits::ET.

detaileddescription.para: Number type used to do the exact computations in the underlying solver for quadratic programs (cf. Implementation).

briefdescription.para: non-mutable model of the STL concept RandomAccessIterator with value type Point.

detaileddescription.para: Used to access the points of the two polytopes.

briefdescription.para: non-mutable model of the STL concept RandomAccessIterator with value type Point.

detaileddescription.para: Used to access the support points.

briefdescription.para: non-mutable model of the STL concept RandomAccessIterator with value type int.

detaileddescription.para: Used to access the indices of the support points in the provided input order (starting from 0 in both point sets).

briefdescription.para: non-mutable model of the STL concept RandomAccessIterator with value type ET.

detaileddescription.para: Used to access the coordinates of the realizing points.

briefdescription.para: initializes poly_dist to $ pd(\emptyset, \emptyset)$.

memberdef.argsstring: (InputIterator1 p_first, InputIterator1 p_last, InputIterator2 q_first, InputIterator2 q_last, const Traits &traits=Traits(), int verbose=0, std::ostream &stream=std::cout)
memberdef.name: Polytope_distance_d

briefdescription.para: initializes poly_dist to $ pd(P,Q)$ with $ P$ and $ Q$ being the sets of points in the range [p_first,p_last) and [q_first,q_last), respectively.

simplesect.para: All points have the same dimension.
If verbose is set to $ 1$, $ 2$, or $ 3$ then some, more, or full verbose output of the underlying solver for quadratic programs is written to stream, resp.

briefdescription.para: returns the dimension of the points in $ P$ and $ Q$.

detaileddescription.para: If poly_dist is $ pd(\emptyset, \emptyset)$, the ambient dimension is $ -1$.

briefdescription.para: returns the number of all points of poly_dist, i.e. $ |P|+|Q|$.
returns the number of points in $ P$.
returns the number of points in $ Q$.
returns the number of support points of poly_dist, i.e. $ |S_P|+|S_Q|$.
returns the number of support points in $ S_P$.
returns the number of support points in $ S_Q$.
returns an iterator referring to the first point in $ P$.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns an iterator referring to the first point in $ Q$.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns an iterator referring to the first support point in $ S_P$.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns an iterator referring to the first support point in $ S_Q$.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns an iterator referring to the index of the first support point in $ P$.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns an iterator referring to the index of the first support point in $ Q$.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns the realizing point of $ P$.

detaileddescription.para:
An implicit conversion from ET to RT must be available.
$ pd(P,Q)$ is finite.

briefdescription.para: returns the realizing point of $ Q$.

detaileddescription.para:
An implicit conversion from ET to RT must be available.
$ pd(P,Q)$ is finite.

briefdescription.para: returns the squared distance of poly_dist, i.e. $ (pd(P,Q))^2$.

detaileddescription.para:
An implicit conversion from ET to RT must be available.
$ pd(P,Q)$ is finite.

briefdescription.para: returns an iterator referring to the first coordinate of the realizing point of $ P$.

simplesect.para: The coordinates have a rational representation, i.e. the first $ d$ elements of the iterator range are the numerators and the $ (d\!+\!1)$-st element is the common denominator.

briefdescription.para: returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns an iterator referring to the first coordinate of the realizing point of $ Q$.

simplesect.para: The coordinates have a rational representation, i.e. the first $ d$ elements of the iterator range are the numerators and the $ (d\!+\!1)$-st element is the common denominator.

briefdescription.para: returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns the numerator of the squared distance of poly_dist.
returns the denominator of the squared distance of poly_dist.
returns true, if $ pd(P,Q)$ is finite, i.e. none of the two polytopes is empty.
returns true, if $ pd(P,Q)$ is zero, i.e. the two polytopes intersect (this implies degeneracy).
returns true, iff $ pd(P,Q)$ is degenerate, i.e. $ pd(P,Q)$ is not finite.
resets poly_dist to $ pd(\emptyset, \emptyset)$.

memberdef.argsstring: (InputIterator1 p_first, InputIterator1 p_last, InputIterator2 q_first, InputIterator2 q_last)
memberdef.name: set

briefdescription.para: sets poly_dist to $ pd(P,Q)$ with $ P$ and $ Q$ being the sets of points in the ranges [p_first,p_last) and [q_first,q_last), respectively.

simplesect.para: All points have the same dimension.

briefdescription.para: sets poly_dist to $ pd(P,Q)$ with $ P$ being the set of points in the range [p_first,p_last) ( $ Q$ remains unchanged).

simplesect.para: All points in $ P$ have dimension poly_dist.ambient_dimension() if $ Q$ is not empty.

briefdescription.para: sets poly_dist to $ pd(P,Q)$ with $ Q$ being the set of points in the range [q_first,q_last) ( $ P$ remains unchanged).

simplesect.para: All points in $ Q$ have dimension poly_dist.ambient_dimension() if $ P$ is not empty.

briefdescription.para: inserts p into $ P$.

simplesect.para: The dimension of p equals poly_dist.ambient_dimension() if poly_dist is not $ pd(\emptyset, \emptyset)$.

briefdescription.para: inserts q into $ Q$.

simplesect.para: The dimension of q equals poly_dist.ambient_dimension() if poly_dist is not $ pd(\emptyset, \emptyset)$.

memberdef.argsstring: (InputIterator1 p_first, InputIterator1 p_last, InputIterator2 q_first, InputIterator2 q_last)
memberdef.name: insert

briefdescription.para: inserts the points in the range [p_first,p_last) and [q_first,q_last) into $ P$ and $ Q$, respectively, and recomputes the (squared) distance.

simplesect.para: All points have the same dimension. If poly_dist is not $ pd(\emptyset, \emptyset)$, this dimension must be equal to poly_dist.ambient_dimension().

briefdescription.para: inserts the points in the range [p_first,p_last) into $ P$ and recomputes the (squared) distance ( $ Q$ remains unchanged).

simplesect.para: All points have the same dimension. If poly_dist is not empty, this dimension must be equal to poly_dist.ambient_dimension().

briefdescription.para: inserts the points in the range [q_first,q_last) into $ Q$ and recomputes the (squared) distance ( $ P$ remains unchanged).

simplesect.para: All points have the same dimension. If poly_dist is not empty, this dimension must be equal to poly_dist.ambient_dimension().

briefdescription.para: returns true, iff poly_dist is valid.

detaileddescription.para: If verbose is true, some messages concerning the performed checks are written to standard error stream. The second parameter level is not used, we provide it only for consistency with interfaces of other classes.

An object poly_dist is valid, iff $ ldots$
poly_dist contains all points of its defining set $ P$,
poly_dist is the smallest sphere containing its support set $ S$,
and $ S$ is minimal, i.e. no support point is redundant.

briefdescription.para: returns a const reference to the traits class object.
writes poly_dist to output stream os.

detaileddescription.para: An overload of operator<< must be defined for Point_d.

briefdescription.para: reads poly_dist from input stream is.

detaileddescription.para: An overload of operator>> must be defined for Point_d.

briefdescription.para: An object of the class Polytope_distance_d represents the (squared) distance between two convex polytopes, given as the convex hulls of two finite point sets in $ d$-dimensional Euclidean space $ \E^d$.

detaileddescription.para: For point sets $ P$ and $ Q$ we denote by $ pd(P,Q)$ the distance between the convex hulls of $ P$ and $ Q$. Note that $ pd(P,Q)$ can be degenerate, i.e. $ pd(P,Q)=\infty$ if $ P$ or $ Q$ is empty.

Two inclusion-minimal subsets $ S_P$ of $ P$ and $ S_Q$ of $ Q$ with $ pd(S_P,S_Q)=pd(P,Q)$ are called pair of support sets, the points in $ S_P$ and $ S_Q$ are the support points. A pair of support sets has size at most $ d+2$ (by size we mean $ |S_P|+|S_Q|$). The distance between the two polytopes is realized by a pair of points $ p$ and $ q$ lying in the convex hull of $ S_P$ and $ S_Q$, repectively, i.e. $ \sqrt{||p-q||}=pd(P,Q)$. In general, neither the support sets nor the realizing points are necessarily unique.

The underlying algorithm can cope with all kinds of input, e.g. $ P$ and $ Q$ may be in non-convex position or points may occur more than once. The algorithm computes a pair of support sets $ S_P$ and $ S_Q$ with realizing points $ p$ and $ q$ which remain fixed until the next set, insert, or clear operation.

Traits
must be a model for PolytopeDistanceDTraits.
We provide the models Polytope_distance_d_traits_2, Polytope_distance_d_traits_3, and Polytope_distance_d_traits_d using the two-, three-, and $ d$-dimensional CGAL kernel, respectively.

The problem of finding the distance between two convex polytopes given as the convex hulls of two finite point sets can be formulated as an optimization problem with linear constraints and a convex quadratic objective function. The solution is obtained using our exact solver for quadratic programs [2].

The creation time is almost always linear in the number of points. Access functions and predicates take constant time, inserting a point might take up to linear time. The clear operation and the check for validity each take linear time.
